placeInfo/address: 4/22 Galkanda Road Aniwatta, Kandy 20000 Sri Lanka
text: Only place we stayed in SL where service and food was less than great. Nasi Goreng with chicken & prawns was disgusting. It was very clearly refried leftovers as it also contained calamari & sausage - which, funnily enough, also featured in their house fried rice. Chicken curry was full of bones. During our first dinner we felt bullied into committing to book for dinner and decide what we would eat on second night there and then.  Stayed for two nights - junior suite down steps beside pool: room was attractively done but no storage at all for clothes apart from a tiny cupboard. Queen's suite was enormous and beautiful but extra bed was in bedroom rather than in huge sitting room, which would have been better.
title: The most disappointing place we stayed in Sri Lanka

ownerResponse/text:
Thank you very much for your candid review of your recent stay at our hotel. Your feedback is extremely valuable to us, as we strive to improve with each and every stay.

Actually, it is due to heavy rain & inclement weather last couple of weeks. however we will come up with a solution in the further, so will not happen again.

We look forward to welcoming you back to our hotel in the near future.

Best Regards 
Kings Pavilion Team
placeInfo/address: 4/22 Galkanda Road Aniwatta, Kandy 20000 Sri Lanka
text:
We visited for 2 nights with my family of 4. We found ourselves quite cramped & as the hotel was full we couldn’t upgrade. However, the welcome was very warm & friendly. The waiting staff that helped with drinks & dinner were ever so attentive & willing to help in any way they could, as were all the staff. 

My only real bugbear with this hotel was the damp smell that we got every time we went in our room or bathroom. I’m not sure if it was because it was particularly wet weather, but it wasn’t overly pleasant. However it didn’t bother us once inside.

It’s a great central location for exploring Kandy & has ever such a pretty garden. It’s a world of calm away from the madness.
title: What the hotel was lacking, the service made up for.

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Guest, 

Thank you for taking the time to share a detailed review of your stay at the Horathapola Estate. We appreciate your honest feedback. 

We regret the inconveniences caused. The management of Horathapola Estate will look into these shortfalls and take necessary steps to enhance the overall experience of our guests.  We assure you of our best attention. 

Thank you once again for choosing to experience Horathapola Estate! 

Best Wishes! 
Management - Horathapola Estate
placeInfo/address: No. 6 Wadumunnegedara, Marawila 60200 Sri Lanka
text:
We stayed at the Horathapola Estate during the last 2 nights of our 2,5 weeks in Sri Lanka. Previous to our stay we did our research and were impressed by the positive reviews. Unfortunately, we can only share part of the enthusiasm. 

Let me beginn with the good part: We did enjoy the colonial, old property, the well-preserved antiques, the quietness of its setting and its amazingly good Sri Lankan cuisine. We were also pampered by all members of the staff and especially by Thamara, who went out of his way to make our stay unique and help with my sick husband.

Now on to the not so good part: based on our previous experiences in Sri Lanka in equally comparable properties (also ancient, colonial houses, some of them also old plantation estates, all of them equally luxurious, some also on half board basis, and all of them in comparable isollated natural settings) we found it terribly overpriced and found their payment policy (cash only) odd to say the least. 

A reason why we might be more critical than other guests is because we visit it at the end of our trip, not at the beginning. Most people visit the Horathapola Estate at the beginning of their journey and I can see why you would be amaze in this case. We on the other side had visited several other properties (in Polonnaruwa, Kandy, Ella, Koslanda, Galle, Hikkaduwa and Induruwa) that could perfectly compete with Horathapola's luxurious comfort YET at a fraction of the price. 

The Horathapola Estate, with a price per night over 300€ (on a Half Board basis) was supposed to be "the cherry on the cake" on our journey. Unfortunately, and based on our experience across other Sri Lanka luxury properties, we were disappointed to see that whilst good, it was at least 100€ / night overpriced. 

Lastly, their payment policiy: "cash only" felt enormously weird and a bit off for a property of this price range. The reasons they gave us for that weren't quite clear either to say the least. It wasn't a problem of cable reception, as they told us that card payment was possible but with an 18% extra charge. Given this outrageous charge, we decided to proceed with cash payment. I mean outrageous such extra carge was never made to us in any of the other luxury accomodations. Where we were always allowed to pay by card, with no extra taxes included / no hidden charges.

We are afraid, based on the above, that we cannot give a 5 star rating to this property.
title: Amazing food and beautiful property BUT way to overpriced and weirdly "cash-only"

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Dilshad, 

Thank you for the honest and valuable feedback. 

We are pleased to hear that you enjoyed the food and the activities we offer at the Horathapola Estate.

Horathapola Estate is an ideal place for those who wish to stay away from all the hustle and bustle and to reconnect with nature. You may have felt a lack of human touch as we allow our guests to embrace the calm and quiet ambiance of the estate. 

However, we once again thank you for experiencing Horathapola and appreciate the time taken to share a review.

Best Wishes!
Management - Horathapola Estate
placeInfo/address: No. 6 Wadumunnegedara, Marawila 60200 Sri Lanka
roomTip: Try their Srilankan menu
text:
The Horathapola estate is perched within a lovely 50 acre coconut estate and has 5 spacious rooms. the collection of antiques, and furniture is impressive. the food is brilliant here, especially the Srilankan lunch. I tried out some western dishes as well and these were prepared well. the pool is fantastic and the garden area and the estate is spacious for those who love a stroll, or go on a bike ride.

the service and the human factor is disappointing. it lacks the human touch. a few details such as cleanliness is required in a few places and the house looks empty as less people work within the main house. visits to the nearby coconut estate and village is something I really enjoyed.
title: Interesting yet slightly disappointing

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Guest,

Many thanks for your review. 

It was a pleasure to host you and we look forward to welcoming you back. 

Best Wishes!

Management - Horathapola Estate
placeInfo/address: No. 6 Wadumunnegedara, Marawila 60200 Sri Lanka
text: This was an ancestral home converted to a hotel, but cannot be rated in the luxury boutique hotel category. A good place for a private holiday, without the frills of a five star hotel. Adequately staffed and you can do your own menu for meals provided it's local cuisine. Suitable for a group of 5 families to enjoy quality time together, as there is no TV. Wifi available!
title: Boutique holiday

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Reviewer, 

Many thanks for your review.  On behalf of the Management of Horathapola Estate, firstly I would like to apologize for your experience. 

We understand that it is rather boring to be isolated, staying far from the hustle and bustle. Hence the reason we have organized activities, such as walks around the village, bullock cart rides, walks around the Estate property and many more. I hope that you were able to experience some of these, if not all. 

We began operations 12 years ago, ever since we did not have Wi-Fi/TV facilities as the hotel has always been a great place to relax and unwind, to be away from the big resorts and busy towns. This certainly has  been the need of our clientele throughout the years. However due to many requests, we understand that it is essential to have Wi-Fi, therefore we will have these facilities installed by the end of this month.

We are glad to know you were happy with the rooms, and yet regret that the food was not up to expectations.  We mainly focus on Authentic Sri Lankan food although we do find out our clients preferences before preparing the meals. 

We are also very sorry that you had to go out of the way to approach our staff, which I believe is absolutely unacceptable. We will take this into serious consideration for our future clients will not experience what you had to go through.

Lastly, our swimming pool is made of cement, it’s a naturally filtered salt water pool. Due to excessive rain the pool tends to look rather murky at times although our staff a Horathapola managers to keep it clean right through. 

We truly appreciate you for sharing the negative points, as it gives us an opportunity to work harder for the future. We will look into each issue in detail, and overcome the shortfalls that you have experienced.  I like to thank you for having  chosen to stay with us and would like to apologize once again for any inconvenience caused. 

Many thanks,
The Management Horathapola Estate
placeInfo/address: No. 6 Wadumunnegedara, Marawila 60200 Sri Lanka
text:
It's too quiet. There is no wifi at all and no TV in the building. It's literally in the middle of nowhere. Pool murky and uninviting. Rooms are beautiful and clean and food is ok but nowhere near as good as elsewhere. If you want a drink or food you have to go and find the staff. I felt like I was inconveniencing the staff. 

After relaxing for an hour it's the most boring place on earth. 

General manager is dour and isn't up to the job of making guests feel welcome. 

Wouldn't return.
title: Didn't like it, sorry

placeInfo/address: No. 6 Wadumunnegedara, Marawila 60200 Sri Lanka
text:
Maybe our stay has been a little bit spoilt by a serious outage that we have experienced during a tropical storm. We stayed in the dark when the night came.
People were really friendly, though.
We found the place a little bit overpriced and difficult to find.
This hotel does not accept visa payment and you have to pay in advance to confirm the reservation.
title: Peaceful place but a little bit pricy

ownerResponse/text:
Critical not harsh...

Thank you for your good custom and interesting feedback, we’re all very sad you left with mixed feelings and, for where we failed. I promise we do try hard to please all of the people all of the time and so, can only apologize for the fact that we couldn’t please you entirely. Thank you at least for noting ‘positives’ at Buckingham Place, below is my reply with respect to your ‘negatives’.

Given that what constitutes quality, style, individuality and good taste is so incredibly subjective, neither your view nor those of hundreds of former guests can be wrong. I reply in defence of my own view however; since 2010, guests have raved about our garden suites - to the extent that one of many ‘regulars’ books the very suite you stayed in each time he visits and, has even asked to buy it! A week prior to your arrival he departed at the end of his 7th 2 week stay in 7 years, and is already planning his next. Pre-season, as we always do, each bedroom and suite was refurbished. Studiously, each was kept as it was when we opened - timeless, understated and simple I'm told. How foolish would I be to change a thing, having been implored by so many not to? I can only be sorry therefore, that our accommodation doesn’t appeal to your particular taste.

Spa. As you haven’t said what disappointed you I can only say; feedback has been superb throughout the spa’s first season, keeping it busy with resident and non-resident guests alike, many on multiple occasions. Please feel free to write and tell me what you didn’t like as, it might be something I can improve on for others. In keeping with the entire property, our spa is meant to be a simple, understated facility as opposed to, over indulgent and/or generic 5* in style and/or service. I do respect your right not to like how we do things!

Communication; 60 Sri Lankans are learning and working hard at Buckingham Place, all year round. Recuited from remote access locations largely, team members excel mostly, and win awards for so doing, in what is essentially an alien environment whilst, conversing in anything but their mother tongue! If Sri Lankans could travel freely as we do, I ask how many would be served by staff conversant with their language (to any extent) or culture? Personally, I think it fair to cut people a little slack whenever I'm unable to make myself understood in Sri Lanka, even if initially, frustration gets the better of me. Having debriefed my team today, our failure was quite simply a collision of frustrating communication failures but, I was present through your stay so naturally ask, why didn't you bring your concerns to me, specifically your belief that vegetarians aren’t adequately catered for here? Nothing is further from the truth in fact, so many pay tribute to this fact on this forum and in other ways.

The hotel is a lifeline and for many staff, an opportunity unimagined or easy to come by. Most lacked employment, prior experience and/or relevant qualifications, while others lacked learning and fulfillment through work. Therefore, your feedback really is important whether we like or agree with it or not. Thanks to it, we've reintroduced two initiatives; dietry consultations (for those with special needs) and emailing of ‘Being Here’ (our in-house guide) to every guest on arrival. It was already the WIFI log-in page and, free to read pre-arrival on our website. 

Buckingham Place will on my watch, remain a small, independent, imaginative alternative to the 'buffets and buses' of large interantional brands. We’ll continue to appreactive and react to feedback because, it makes us better at times, just as it has done with yours. I wish we’d pleased you but, blame only myself for being unable to. Though unlikely I know, I'd relish the opportunity to show you Buckingham Place in a better light and 'get you on board' with what we do. I assure you of a warm welcome should you ever wish to return, in the meantime I wish you many happy and varied travel experiences!
 
Warm regards,
Nick & the Team
placeInfo/address: Rekawa Beach Road Rekawa Village, Rekawa, Tangalle 82200 Sri Lanka
text:
We spent 4 nights here as part of our honeymoon and had a mixed experience.

Starting with the positives, staff were extremely friendly, with Nick and his team going out of their way to make us feel welcome.  They provided a honeymoon chocolate cake at the beginning and end of our stay and a lovely card which was signed by the whole team.

The pool is the highlight and is every bit as impressive in real life as in the pictures. It’s a really beautiful space and despite the hotel being fairly busy when we visited, there were always plenty of sunloungers available.  We loved the fact that board games are provided and we also made good use of the Pool/Snooker table.

On the downside, we didn’t think the rooms were brilliant, particularly the bathroom. We struggled a bit with the food and found options for vegetarians rather limited. We mentioned this to Nick and he put it down as a communication issue.

The spa was a disappointment and although the service at the hotel is very friendly and well-intentioned we sometimes struggled to be understood, for example if we asked for something that they don’t have, like brown bread, the waiter would say that he will bring it and then it would never arrive. 

It’s clear from these reviews that people love Buckingham Place but we didn’t quite get it and found it to be extremely expensive given our overall experience.  We left early to return to a 5* place on the other side of Tangalle where for a few more dollars you get a completely different experience.

Finally, Nick was lovely throughout and I feel harsh writing a slightly critical review of something that is obviously so popular, but for the sake of balance I think it’s only fair to share our experience.
title: Mixed Feelings

ownerResponse/text:
Firstly, thank you for coming to stay and then, for reviewing the hotel afterwards. Though saddened by it, I view what you say as quite helpful as it might inspire travelers to research more thoroughly before selecting this or any other hotel. These days there are abundant resources to reference – including for Buckingham Place. Our own website for example, includes amongst many useful features, named room photos with good descriptions, location information, even a swimming advisory - most hotels are not so candid! We truthfully describe our property as being at a remote access location, on a wilderness beach, on the edge of a nature sanctuary as well as; Rekawa beach being un-swimmable from, deliberately to avoid guests being surprisingly disappointed. Trip Advisor – not only for traveler reviews is another resource. One can view 900+ photos on this site mostly taken by guests plus, even more can be found on Instagram and Facebook. 

Strangely, you gave us no reason to believe at the time, you were not actually enjoying your stay, so naturally I’m surprised and sad to learn ours was your least favorite hotel. Overwhelmingly, as you may have noted, so many reviewers describe it as their most favorite - often in the entire world! The many accolades on this site not least 9 Travelers Choice Awards this year alone (Sri Lanka/Asia/World) plus, its #1 ranking above all Sri Lankan hotels for more than 5 years (at time of reply) suggests to me at least, that we must be doing something right and the property must suit the overwhelming majority of its patrons. As you rightly suggest, you’re recounting an experience of the hotel not judging me (or other hotels?) which, is wholly fair and sensible. I do believe however, had your research been thorough you might have judged the hotel as ‘not for me’ before choosing it – review scores alone are inadequate I believe, as no two #1’s are the same or even similar in my experience.

Before finishing I will correct you on several points that would mislead others. Having applied for the original planning consent I’m qualified to say the hotel is NOT several hundred metres from the beach. Edge of pool to beach is 60m (with direct access from our own beach land), centre of restaurant to beach is 75m and, whilst the spectacular elevated view is of the sea not beach, that is because beach vegetation is protected by law, especially in a wildlife habitat. From our front gate to the beach is just 75m and from your room to the beach I estimate is 150m max. Sun loungers are not squashed in anywhere and can be found scattered throughout the 5 acre property. Granted, guests may well move them at their will! As for atmosphere? This is where I did wonder at first whether indeed you were reviewing this hotel. This is one of just a handful of southern hotels known to me and friends, renowned for having one and, one reason so many guests return – not for readymade hotel nightlife/entertainment I hasten to add but, for the conviviality of its guests and yes, its owner too. A classic jazz/swing background most evenings adds something too I'm told, but generally its the charming and sociable personalities of our guests that make this place 'tick'.  

When more than 95% of our guests rave in some way or another about the hotel and its team, I would be a fool to change a thing unless of course I could improve it still further. I’m genuinely sorry our hotel wasn’t for you but, seek to reassure all readers of this reply that, I and my team of 55 Sri Lankans try everything possible to make it special for everyone.
. 
Likewise I wish you well and hope you’ll give this hotel another chance to impress you one day.

Best wishes, 
Nick.
placeInfo/address: Rekawa Beach Road Rekawa Village, Rekawa, Tangalle 82200 Sri Lanka
text:
Buckingham Place is situated 20 minutes or so from Tangalle and set several hundred meters back from the beach with is not swimmable and as such is somewhat bleak.

The restaurant and pool hold a view of the sea but not of the beach.

We stayed in a standard double (no5) which over looked the room directly in front - the room was uninspiring; very large but lacking any charm or character.

We have stayed in nine hotels in Sri Lanka, some luxury but mainly "boutique" but surprisingly (given the reviews) Buckingham Place is our least favourite.
.
Having read the excellent reviews on Trip Advisor I did spend the first few days wondering if we were in the same hotel!

The hotel has had a major change with the opening of the new pool, dining room, bar etc. the pool is very large (looks great) but dominates the area and squashes the sun beds in on either side. The large dining area lacks atmosphere. The old pool (which is now the quiet pool) and garden is a lovely environment and I can imagine how the old restaurant would have been a far more socially interactive, cosy space.

Nick, the owner of the property and the subject of many of the previous reviews, is indeed a pleasant man but my review is based on the property and my experience not on an individual.

Whilst I feel annoyed at this property for disappointing us at the end of what was otherwise a great trip (we had stayed at two other property's prior to Buckingham Place on this holiday) it would be unfair to rate the hotel as less than average; the food is good (but takes forever) and they provided a kind surprise to help celebrate an anniversary. The service is fine but not exceptional (we have never really received bad service in Sri Lanka). 

I wish Nick and the team well but the above is an honest representation of my experience – we never really ‘got’ Buckingham Place.
title: Surprisingly disappointing!!

ownerResponse/text:
I’m bewildered as to why some people prefer to complain after the event and give not the slightest hint of dissatisfaction at the time of it..! 

I’m bewildered too as to how in this ‘information age’ travellers in search of swimming beaches could so mistakenly choose an hotel which candidly and caringly volunteers advise that its nearby beach is unsuitable for swimming and, where its owner regularly and heartily thanks his former guests for saying so in their Trip Advisor reviews.
 
So, I must thank you first as I do all others, for your timely reminder not to swim from Rekawa Beach within the immediate vicinity of the hotel. Whilst so doing however, I draw your kind attention and that of all readers, to a sentence in the review immediately preceding yours (I hope they won’t mind), “We particularly enjoyed taking the hotel bikes along the small tracks of Rekawa village and finding hidden coves and beaches for swimming”. These guests, and in fact too many others to mention (several less able and/or elderly guests – myself included) thoroughly enjoy sea bathing within easy reach of the hotel with quite a number being kind about our modest 10 x 4m ‘cooling off’ swimming pool into the bargain! I think you’re the first to complain about the slight effort required to walk up the beach a bit, to enjoy yourselves in the sea, and reply; I’m sorry but you are simply wrong about how difficult it is to get in the sea within a fairly short time and believe, one really must take location and climate into account when researching and planning overseas travel – especially to the tropics. I add to what I say by pasting in this from our website Info Page: ‘Swimming. Rekawa Beach is breathtakingly beautiful and usually deserted. Sea bathing is not advised within the immediate vicinity of the hotel but a nearby rock pool (c15 minute walk) and much safer beaches are easily accessed by Tuk Tuk. For cooling off under the sun our modest hotel pool is adequate for most and, not overly challenging’. A final note on swimming; the hotel is not a ‘water-park’ nor is this Saint Tropez but, a long infinity lapping pool with additional pool bar is quietly nearing completion (opens later this year I hope) on adjoining beach front land. With the sole aim of pleasing everyone, after commissioning the new pool we’ll keep the existing, much loved one full of water and open.
 
Isolation. Isolation, stunning flora and fauna, a peaceful sanctuary to ‘get away from it all’ is the whole point of this hotel – I’m not sure how you missed this simple, widely accessible message? Website information points to it and guests regularly pay tribute to the fact that the hotel and Rekawa are loved overwhelmingly for the reasons above – if you don’t believe me please read the hotels current Trip Advisor page, all previous ones and our website. I’m delighted to add too, higher numbers than imagined or dreamt of are returning to Buckingham Place - for its isolation, ethos and excellent service I’m told. Even I didn’t anticipate how popular this small, isolated, unassuming hotel might become!
  
Don’t choose this hotel if: you like flexibility in your vacation. I consider this view utterly lacking in foundation and credibility! If you had taken time to notice fellow guests, those who chose, kept perfectly busy in and around the hotel and by venturing further afield. As I write, during our long and lazy breakfast session I see happy, contented travellers who have; whale watched, surfed, canoed, cycled and visited, national parks and rock temples, a rain forest, the local markets, swimming beaches and beach-shack restaurants – all from this very isolated access challenged hotel. Thankfully there are no jet-skis, oligarch super-yachts or boom-boom nightclubs in Rekawa… just yet. 

Don’t choose this hotel if: you’re looking for a diverse food experience. 5 x Connoisseur house teas, freshly ground Sri Lankan coffee beans roasted then sent monthly from the highlands by taxi; 12 x unique a la carte Breakfast menu choices (or suggest your own combo), 16 x Snack menu choices (small and light/large and filling), 35 x Main menu items across the board over five, daily changing menus plus, many more ideas ‘up our sleeve’ and available on request (just as we advise clearly on arrival). All the special diets/cuisines and effort to please on offer here tell another and quite unique story to the one you tell – the exact opposite to your unjust criticism in fact. Why didn’t you, as our guests are invited to, simply ask for suggestions if none of our tried, tested and printed repertoire whetted your appetite? I find this incredulous. 

Finally on this subject, a typical menu and comprehensive information on dining can be found at our website and, many constructive reviews have been submitted by diners who would in very large number I’m sure, contradict and perhaps ridicule you most vociferously! Sure we’re not perfect, not by any means, but with a small handful at least of (what some diners tell us are) world class dishes, our all Sri Lankan kitchen crew is much better than you give it credit for being as are our service levels for which we are currently ranked as a Travellers Choice #2 in Sri Lanka in addition to ranking #1 in the Best Small Hotels category.

I take great exception to what I consider an irresponsible comment (one clearly meant to damage a good reputation); ‘armies of mosquitoes’ and fairly ask, why you didn’t you mention them at the time if this was indeed true? Why would anyone not tell us if the 'flying ants' that evening were actually mosquitoes? We could then be expected and rightly so, to take action to eradicate them. FYI; at considerable expense a contractor fogs the entire property every 2 weeks with eco/animal friendly insect repelling/killing products. This precautionary measure is simply the action of a responsible hotelier and hotel resident. I live here year round too, using neither repellents, medicines nor even plug-ins or coils. For hygiene and aesthetic reasons we do not (there’s no need) install nets in accommodation but instead pay exemplary attention to the potential issue. Inevitably a few mosquitoes survive and prosper, we are after all in the tropics. But largely as I suspect was the case, what you really experienced were short-lived flying ants or similar which come and go in a matter of minutes/hours, usually after short cloud bursts (they are generally attracted to light). These flying irritants are regularly the subject of mistaken identity. 

For perspective, on a warm September evening in southern France last year I was bitten more times on the terrace of a friends’ apartment than I might ever expect to be through spending a year in Rekawa! As for no walks without torches and being ushered back to your room? Your comment is frankly insulting. We try to avoid excessive light pollution largely for aesthetics hence the low-level garden lighting and, the Team is trained to exercise thoughtful care of guests along with good manners. I’m sorry to note you misunderstood our good intent, most guests actually appreciate us caring and good manners and compliment us on this initiative. Once again, did you say anything at the time? I think not - we would not have wasted our time if you had. 

Hot bathroom. Since 17th December 2014 until today, for all but 5 nights, your bedroom has been occupied by resident guests I'm happy to say. Not one has mentioned a thing out of the ordinary even during this current hot spell. Nor incidentally, have they complained of so called ‘armies’ of mosquitoes which I believe is a scurrilous accusation. All the same, I don’t dismiss your comment about a hot bathroom and, will look into it later today or tomorrow. Again though, why didn’t you simply mention this at the time? For your comfort we would have happily installed a movable stand fan within minutes if you had only requested us to.

Towel changes. Our policy is to change towels and bed linens every other day or beforehand if necessary and/or requested. I consider it inexcusable therefore, that we didn’t replace your towels after a second night. Please note; we respectfully ask guests to deposit towels in the linen basket for more frequent changes if so desired. I have investigated the matter and the room Team has been re-trained this morning. I apologise unreservedly for our service failure and thank you for bringing it to my attention. However, this or any other matter you’ve raised could have been resolved so easily and painlessly in minutes, had you only thought to mention it at the time.
 
Your statement; ‘we were checking out a day ahead of time, and while the owner wasn’t there at that moment, no one even asked why we decided to leave abruptly’ is according to my information, somewhat economical with the truth. I was actually in contact from Colombo with our GM and restaurant Captain on your early departure while on business. Both informed me independently that when asked, your partner informed them your travel plans had unavoidably changed and also, that you were happy with the Team and your stay at the hotel overall. I of course instructed them to waive any charge for your late cancelled night – our lost business. I’m therefore utterly mystified by your unfair assertion that we didn’t care. Had we not, surely we would have charged you for the night you cancelled at short notice? Unlike normal practise elsewhere and contrary even to our own policy of inadequate notice, we didn’t charge you – instead we felt sorry for you because you misled us to believe you had no choice other than change your planned itinerary!  I and my colleagues feel justifiably aggrieved by this obvious misrepresentation of fact and surprised too that our generosity has been conveniently overlooked. Ironically, guests occupying your room prior to you extended their stay with a late check out, they thoroughly enjoyed the room and their stay in it and didn't want to leave the hotel I recall... 
 
I hope that in a roundabout way your review and my customary reply underline the strengths of this establishment and Team. For example; integrity (candid and caring swimming advice) and willingness to go to any length, to welcome, satisfy and care for all guests like they’re family. I’m deeply saddened all the same, that since showing enthusiasm and appreciation for the hotel on the occasions we met and, considering the overriding ethos of this place (‘we recognise you’re on holiday, therefore everything must be perfect - just tell us if it’s not’ – my words upon introducing myself) you have judged the hotel with so little consideration for a Teams morale or its good reputation. It seems unfair that simply because you failed to research and choose accommodation more suited to your swimming needs, we’re left wondering how we can please everybody all of the time - other than try to of course. We also ponder a small mystery, what makes people resolve to say nothing of their dissatisfaction at the actual time they’re given every opportunity and are actually invited to do so?

I respectfully suggest that hotels like ours may well not ‘click’ for you in anything like the way this one does for the vast, overwhelming majority of its guests or in the way you seem to think they should.

Please do not return. 

Yours sincerely,
Nick & the Team.
placeInfo/address: Rekawa Beach Road Rekawa Village, Rekawa, Tangalle 82200 Sri Lanka
text:
Choose this hotel if:
- you want to spend a few days away from civilisation
- you’re interested in wildlife

Don’t choose this hotel if:
- you like swimming
- you like flexibility in your vacation
- you’re looking for a diverse food experience

A bit more in detail: isolated location

The hotel is located in a wild place 12 km away from the nearest town. Part of this way is a narrow, bumpy forest road. If you’re interested in local restaurants, markets, etc - you’re not getting them here. If you want to run away from civilisation - then it’s a different story.

Close to wildlife

It’s close to the jungle, which means you can share breakfast with a peacock or see monkeys drinking water from the pool. But be aware that this also includes armies of mosquitoes and no evening walks without a light torch. Actually, they’ll usher you straight to the room from the restaurant.

Deal breaker for us: no swimming

And here comes the part which became the deal breaker for us, who love water. There is no swimming experience here. The beach is just 50 m away, but you can only admire the ocean there without entering it - blame the big waves. 

The nearest ‘rock pool’ where the waves aren’t dangerous is in a 25-min walk - not so easy to cover that distance in tropical heat. The nearest safe beach is a 30 min ride by tuk-tuk. And the small hotel pool will only work for a quick dip. 

Room

Every room is located in a separate building with lake view. It’s quite spacious and comfortable, but the bathroom is way too warm though - it has a glass roof which turns it into a greenhouse. Definitely motivates for a very quick shower. 

Also, the room service was a bit strange - the towels weren’t changed in 3 days. I guess you need to specifically request that.

Restaurant: limited choices

The food was good, but a choice from 3 options for dinner seemed a bit limited. I think it could be an issue if we stayed longer - as I mentioned, the town is 12 km away, so going to a different restaurant is a difficult quest.

One more thing I would mention is that there’s room for improvement in service. We were checking out a day ahead of time, and while the owner wasn’t there at that moment, no one even asked why we decided to leave abruptly.

I wouldn’t say that Buckingham place is a bad hotel. Seeing the wild nature was an interesting experience, but other than that it didn’t click with us.

We would not come back to this hotel.
title: Not a place for those who like swimming

ownerResponse/text:
Thank you for coming to stay and for following up with helpful feedback. Naturally I prefer to read only glowing testimonials and therefore I’m sad upon reading yours. I do respect your overall view and right to express it of course, regardless of how out of step it seems when compared to so many others. 

Firstly, Buckingham Place tries hard to and generally does exceed the expectations of its guests, while providing a unique alternative to the typically soulless, generic opulence and in my view, irritating pampering of so-called designer (chic?) hotels. However, regardless of what we try to do, we can be human and fail sometimes. From what you say it appears we might have failed in certain instances so I apologize unreservedly for the sense of disappointment you feel. 

Marketing; the hotels website images (including interiors) are deliberately ones taken by amateurs – former guests mainly. I write/update all website copy to avoid ‘advertising gloss’ and our guests frequently remark that it’s down to earth honesty and images don’t actually do justice to the hotel at all and, certainly don’t oversell it. I therefore fail to understand what more I can do to ensure every guest knows exactly what to expect when they arrive, other than advice as I do, to start their research by acquainting themselves with the hotels website and, to view some of the 1000’s of unsolicited images and videos posted online by former guests. Whilst recognizing not every traveler has the time or inclination to look at a hotels website and research it thoroughly, I do advise everyone to make sure prior to booking that the hotel and its culture are of the style and kind normally desired and above all, that the hotel charge rates fall within their budget range - so they have no need to worry what they are spending or go without. Though very helpful, Trip Advisor rankings are by no means a substitute for proper research.

Service; Team training has remained a constant since 2 years prior to opening the hotel. In this and all areas of the business investment is heavy, sustained and regularly produces minor miracles. The food you enjoyed was cooked and served by former (under-employed/unemployed) fishers and farmers largely, none of whom had experience prior to joining us. In fact the current team (numbering some 42) benefits year round from well remunerated employment (not seasonal), 3 meals a day, accommodation assistance, continuous development opportunity, pensions, medical and other welfare support. Also, in spite of our advice “only tip if we exceed expectations and then please do so at the end if you wish” – guest gratuities are significantly higher than many hotels. Buckingham Place service is meant first and foremost to be genuine. The Team is taught the importance of anticipation, genuine warmth, friendliness and professionalism. Sincerity is what guests repeatedly tell us they find here, not slick silver-service or overly servile robots. Front of house staff are much more likely to be sincere than ‘in ones face’ or forever pestering or ‘selling up’. Our Team is not meant to be a throwback to long gone colonial days nor are its members chosen for their looks, age, gender or past experience – they are chosen first as people, who like all of us are fallible at times. 

Other issues; our entire bed sheet stock was replaced this season with 100% Indian cotton/high thread count items. It is policy that where possible and certainly where necessary or requested, bed linen is changed daily or every other day and, we do so with rare exception. However, earlier high rainfall throughout Sri Lanka, the worst in 57 years, caused long turnaround delays at the (outsourced) laundry. Regrettably, while the laundry caught up with its massive backlog every hotel in the area suffered operational headaches. I’m very sorry we inconvenienced you, didn’t inform you, and didn’t do better in this regard. Please also note; housekeeping staff are trained to avoid disturbing guest’s sanctuary to clean rooms. I’m informed of instances when they were unable to access your suite. Bathroom products; coincidently, while at this point in my reply, I have just asked house-keeping staff to make up a package for a departing guest, to include all of the complimentary items you complain about. Hardly a day goes by without a guest requesting we do this. I have answered this criticism before and since added additional high quality foam bath, body wash and an alternative shampoo, strangely though, it’s the excellent (but cheap) ayurvedic products people ask for most to take home and therefore, we would be foolish to dispense with them. I can only say sorry you didn’t like them! Quality of service/attentiveness of staff; I was at the hotel during your 4 night stay and can honestly say that I did not witness a shortfall in service but then I rarely saw you at the restaurant. Neither did you bring to my attention (or that of my General Manager) even a hint of dissatisfaction or disappointment which, we invite all guests to do the very moment they arrive at the hotel and then again in our in room guide ‘It’s Only Common Sense’ – so we are all surprised to read this now. 

Design of interiors; please see my earlier reference to the hotel website and the 1000’s of images online. Minibar we don’t install them – we prefer instead to provide room service and fairly priced beverages. We do provide a small refrigerator in each bedroom/suite, sometimes guests purchase exotic fruits when out for example, so we provide the means to keep them cool along perhaps, with a half full bottle of wine purchased at the restaurant which, they did not consume immediately. We also stock the refrigerator with some fairly unusual complimentary snack items - you may have noticed them. Rooms; Chic modernist? I neither aspire nor pretend to align the hotel with a specific style genre as I have no wish to alienate guests (the overwhelming majority) who choose the hotel for its unique personality and values not its fashion statement.

Location; I chose the location of the hotel for its remote natural setting not its close proximity to nightlife and beach restaurant life. This point we make clear on our website and elsewhere and, it was made very clear throughout my colleagues correspondence with you “We can suggest alternatives to our restaurant and do so based on positive feedback from guests. There are a couple of restaurants I will be happy to guide you to at the time. Generally speaking there are alternatives at various levels within a c25-30 minute tuk-tuk ride”.
Your observation; not once were we offered a glass of water. Every single sunny day the Team deliver complimentary water or various types of cool drink to guests relaxing in the main garden. It’s just possible you weren’t around when we did but if you were then I apologize for our oversight and, promise to monitor this in future.   

Throughout your stay, whenever we conversed, I felt I was being questioned continually. You appeared preoccupied with an earlier booking/rates issue and how much everything was costing but curious too, to know how easy it was to buy land in Sri Lanka and so on. So much so it occurred to me briefly, you might be contemplating building your own hotel in Sri Lanka or already own one – I am often asked such things. I am sorry as I said before, that when reserving via a third party partner you were confused by what appeared to be a much lower rate. As my colleague explained in his correspondence and, when I discussed the issue with you, rates are exactly the same whether one books through our website or that of a third party and, the third parties do make clear that local taxes etc will be charged at the hotel.

My conclusion; I reply as robustly as you review but truly believe there must be merit in some of your service shortfall issues. For these I can only apologize for again and look out for in future. Overall however, I think the rates we charge may well have clouded your view, especially noticing how much happier you were at a guest house (also reviewed) in the Rs.2500 price band. To build, equip staff, operate and to maintain a hotel and deliver international standards, by the sea, in the tropics, in a developing country, is a costly business indeed – after 12 years I await return on substantial investment. For a Team to fully anticipate every conceivable need of foreign speaking tourists arriving from entirely different cultures means, challenges will inevitably arise. How we recognize and overcome those challenges will inevitably lead to how we as guests in another country are judged.

Thank you again for coming to stay, I’m sorry we disappointed you and that you missed the very essence of Buckingham Place. Please feel free to return, I would welcome the opportunity to host you again and hopefully, change your perception of what this hotel is all about.

Yours sincerely and on behalf of the Team,
Nick
placeInfo/address: Rekawa Beach Road Rekawa Village, Rekawa, Tangalle 82200 Sri Lanka
text:
I booked this placed after seeing it listed among “top 25 hotels in Asia” in 2 different categories on TripAdvisor. Naturally, that set the expectations very high. 
I am comparing this hotel to a number of similarly priced (say $200-400 range) hotels, mostly of similar style (detached huts/houses, beach-side), and in somehow similar destinations (tropical developing countries, e.g. India, Thailand, Burma, Mexico, Vietnam, Seychelles, etc). 

I believe this is a nice hotel, with a few features which are certainly above average (food; beautiful deserted beach; size of rooms) and a few which are below average (quality of service/attentiveness of staff; design of interiors; quality of products used in bathrooms, bed linens, minibar, etc; little touches, or rather lack of those, which distinguish outstanding hotels). Please don’t get me wrong, it was a nice enough place, but for those 5 star ratings to have any meaning, I believe they should be reserved for the truly outstanding, breath-taking properties which are a class apart in their respective price ranges. 

My rationale when choosing this hotel was: the location is somehow remote, the beach (per owner’s own admission) un-swimmable, the property facing away from the beach. It’s in those slightly less-than-perfect locations that outstanding value-for-money hotels are often found: what costs have been saved on rent/purchase of land, can be ploughed back into providing exceptional service. I thought the quality of service and accommodation was fair, but far from exceptional. 

Rather than repeat what’s already been said in other 3-star reviews, just a few points. Rooms are admittedly of very large size, yes, but rather than chic modernist, a bit bland and empty in my view. Toiletries are of the cheap, local sort, with prices of $0.50-$1 clearly showing on the boxes. I understand that the intention was to provide ayurvedic, local toiletries but in a 5-star hotel it should be expected that top-quality local stuff is sourced. 

And then the service.. Bed linens were not changed daily, in fact we had to ask after third night to have them changed. When we were spending a full day by the pool, not once were we offered a glass of water – it’s not that difficult to figure out that when a hotel is completely removed from local shops where water bottles could be bought, people will want to have something to drink when spending several hours in the sun. It’s this anticipation of guests’ needs, or rather complete lack of it, that I thought was rather disappointing. “We felt like we had to ask for everything” is a quote from another review, so clearly I’m not the only one here. It’s possible to feel absolutely pampered in some other hotels in Asia costing ½ the price. $150/night used to buy me things such as: several times a day room service, done seamlessly whenever we left the room, making sure that we never returned to empty water bottles, unmade bed, etc; refreshments (just a glass of icy water would do!) brought to us by the pool, or fresh pool towels; returning to our room in the evening to find candles lit, or fresh flowers arranged on return from breakfast; even more ridiculous things e.g. personalised news digest delivered daily in the morning.  I’m not saying I expect all of the above, but if nothing apart from the most basic, once a day room service is offered, I can’t really understand why Buckingham Place is listed as top #1 hotel for service in the country. To be fair, when we did ask for things, we got them – e.g. a local newspaper or change of bed sheets. But that’s completely expected in a  $300/night property. 

Finally, the location – beach is stunning, yes, but the hotel is really far from any other restaurants, shops, etc. I had been assured the nearest beach-side restaurant was 2km away – it’s more like 4km, which Google Maps confirms. We braved the walk on 2 occasions, but I doubt many other guests will want to. Meaning that all meals will have to be taken in the hotel’s own restaurant – very nice food, but the total bill for 2 will then easily exceed $150/day for food and modest amounts of drinks alone. 

Stunning empty beach, huge rooms & amazing fusion breakfasts. Other aspects are a bit disappointing though.
title: Stunning empty beach, huge rooms & amazing fusion breakfasts. Disappointing service though

ownerResponse/text:
We’re sorry...

Firstly, thank you for choosing Buckingham Place and following up your stay with this helpful feedback. Whilst much happier to read ‘rave reviews’ I must take it on the chin if we get it wrong. To my knowledge, not since 2012 has a guest expressed such disappointment on Trip Advisor and I thank you for at least highlighting the ‘positives’ of your short stay and for ticking average as your overall ‘score’. 

Measuring up to expectations generated by so many incredible reviews and our position in the marketplace is obviously challenging, perhaps even impossible? Constantly we strive to bring happiness to our guests but sadly, on this occasion, we owe an apology. Attentive service, a more imaginative packed breakfast and good towels are of course, wholly reasonable expectations. With regards several issues I’m afraid we failed to communicate effectively. For example; our restaurant serves diners whenever they choose to eat - as policy. Meal times and indeed menu choices are frequently tailored to suit individuals - we often find ourselves serving breakfast and a bespoke lunch simultaneously, late into the afternoon at that! Normally too, we happily cater for early risers, vegetarians or guests with special dietary requirements by consultation, and rarely do we disappoint. As for concrete floors and blankets in rooms? At the helpful suggestion of former guests we offer ‘take home’ flip-flops to any guest not familiar or comfortable with these typically tropical floors and blankets to those who like to switch off the air-conditioning at night. Please don’t misunderstand, I don't refute anything you say nor, offer feeble excuses, to the contrary. I apologise for not clearly highlighting the above messages.

I would like to explain my thinking on a couple of points. Bathroom products; these local ayurvedic products were chosen to be in keeping with the simplicity or ‘opulence free’ Sri Lankan personality of the hotel. In defence of quality, when using the shampoo personally, my hair stops falling out and hardly a week passes by without guests complimenting the products or requesting samples to take home – they are incredibly popular notwithstanding the awful cardboard box packaging! As a traveller, too many times I find a multitude of bland, ineffective products in my bathroom, most of which irritate me as they are merely a branding exercise for the hotel. Marshmallows; a small selection of Sri Lankan sweets, freshly pan roasted peanuts plus, a couple of apples and juice cartons are stocked in the mini-fridge, just in case a ravenous guest should arrive. All are provided fresh and with our compliments. Admittedly unusual, this alternative to generic tins of stale crisps and other ludicrously priced mini-bar items we are told is fun and a refreshing change.

Much of what we do at Buckingham Place is based on my own observations, preferences and gripes as a traveller or the suggestions of former guests. The hotels architecture, interiors and overall culture is a deliberate breakaway from the more commonly found colonial pastiche, and as this isn’t everybody’s cup of tea, clear descriptions and images can be viewed on our website plus, additional candid images and descriptions of the hotel can be found on Trip Advisor. To apologise for my own tastes and for what to date has brought much joy to so many would be insincere, I hope you can appreciate that, I’m just very sorry and sad that it didn’t please you.
 
Since reading your review I’ve contacted the Team to discuss your comments in more detail - specifically to find remedies for our failings. You have focused me on our weaknesses for which I thank you, I can only apologise for getting it wrong. I would naturally welcome an opportunity to host you once again so that we might get it right and, hope that our shortcoming didn't detract from your holiday in Sri Lanka overall.
   
Best wishes,
Nick & the Team
placeInfo/address: Rekawa Beach Road Rekawa Village, Rekawa, Tangalle 82200 Sri Lanka
text:
We have just returned from two weeks in Sri Lanka and we had the pleasure of staying in 7 hotels during our stay. We chose Buckingham Place as one of these hotels as we had read such incredible reviews on TripAdvisor. I guess as a result we had high expectations!

The positives: 
1) The hotel is located near a beautiful, litter free beach which was a delight for morning/afternoon walks. It is just a couple of mins walk from the hotel. 
2) Ginger and the wildlife - we love animals so it was a pleasure to get to know Ginger the horse and the other animals that live at Buckingham Place including a couple of dogs, peacocks and various other birds. This was our highlight of the stay.
3) The restaurant/bar area is pleasant and the grounds are well looked after.

What didn't work for us:
1)	Service - we felt like we had to ask for EVERYTHING - I have to be honest but the service was really quite bad. Everyone was pleasant and smiled but nobody seemed particularly on the ball with anything. One time (when we were at the pool) I had to go to the restaurant three times just to ask for a glass of water. Generally I just felt that staff weren't very proactive.They were nice and polite but they need training.

2)	Food – Don't get me wrong, the food was actually good when it came, but the staff weren't very helpful dealing with dietary requirements. I am a vegetarian and the menus didn't really cater to me - 3 nights in a row the vegetarian option for dinner was curry. This is not a problem in itself but in this case it would have been helpful if the staff were a bit more forthcoming with offering alternatives and suggestions on what they could provide. Instead it was more of a case of us going to them and asking / suggesting what they could cook. At most other hotels the staff were really good at handling this and would come up to us each day to discuss meals and what they could offer.

We went on an early day trip one morning and had to leave at 6am. We asked if the hotel could provide us a packed breakfast for us as we had a long journey. We were quite disappointed to find that the breakfast was a packet of lemon cream biscuits and a couple of pieces of fruit. While the kitchen may not have been open, I have stayed at a lot of hotels and had a lot of packed breakfasts in my time and this was by far the worst! We could have stopped on a road side and picked this up. Even a couple of pieces of bread would have been better. Again, it’s not a problem really, but when you are paying USD 300 a night you just expect a bit more. 

Breakfast started at 8.30am as they do a 'lazy breakfast'. We felt this was too late. Similarly, lunch started at 1pm. I think they need to revise the timings slightly to allow people to eat earlier (e.g. 730am and 12.30pm)

4) The rooms - we were disappointed with the rooms, various comments as follows:
- Rooms are really big and very clean but our room (Presidential Suite I believe) was a bit soulless. The rooms are just concrete blocks.
 - No mini bar in rooms (there was a fridge with some old looking marshmallows and two cartons of fruit juice drink - bit strange) 
- No extra blanket/duvet in the room - the air con in the room was fierce and it would have been nice to have an extra blanket in the room available to use. Again we had to ask for this and were given two extra bed sheets (I guess they don't have blankets)
- No robes and rubbish towels / not enough towels
- The toiletries they offered (soap etc) were basically cheap local products in old dirty cardboard boxes. A bar of soap for the shower and no conditioner, shower gel etc (would definitely recommend bringing your own)
-Concrete floors were slippery - my partner nearly fell over twice

Our overall feeling was one of disappointment. Of all the hotels we stayed in during our two weeks it was our least favourite. We left just feeling a bit uncertain about our overall experience. Some of these points are a bit pernickety and we're not really like that as travellers but I think the point is that for USD 300 a night we expected more. While many of these points are small and individually overlooked, there were just too many small things which added up and left us feeling a bit underwhelmed (and at some points irritated).
title: We didn't really get this place...

ownerResponse/text:
Thank you for coming to stay at Buckingham Place and for submitting a review to Trip Advisor. 

Thankfully overall, you experienced a pleasant stay, although you have raised several points of dissatisfaction which I respond to in order and in full.

Firstly, I’m sorry that you nearly slipped on a cement floor; it would certainly sadden us were a guest to fall or hurt themselves or, if they were even anxious about doing so. Cement floors are for many including me, an attractive architectural feature. They are used almost as widely as ceramic tiles throughout Sri Lanka, largely for practicality, organic appearance and because hard wood forests are have been depleted and carpeting is impractical in the tropics. Deliberately, we use rough-cut granite in (wet) bathrooms and have not polished a single cement floor for over 2 years now. Responsibly, we offer cautionary advice about wet feet and/or floors both verbally on arrival and in our in-room pamphlet entitled “It’s Only Common Sense’.

We choose not to provide ‘brew facilities’ in bedrooms or suites unless asked to. Instead we serve freshly ground coffee and high-grown teas from Sri Lanka’s top estates. This is in preference to typical sachets of processed and generally tasteless generic refreshment given free in city hotel rooms and elsewhere. This quality first policy helps maintain standards in terms of hygiene, cleanliness and guest satisfaction. Pots of connoisseur tea and large French presses of coffee can be served to guest accommodation before breakfast and are included as part of breakfast. Guests can also ask for ‘refills’ - these too are included in our overnight rates. That you were mistakenly charged is a training issue - now in hand. I sincerely apologise for this and ask that you please email us requesting a full refund of this charge. If you had brought this mistake to our attention after checking your final bill the amount would have been deducted without question. Unfortunately, your review is anonymous and therefore I can do nothing further until I hear from you personally I’m afraid. I naturally apologise for our error and for any inconvenience caused.

As we highlight on guest arrival and/or in information provided prior to it; “meal orders can take slightly longer than elsewhere in the world and so we respectfully request the kind patience of all diners. We do not use microwave ovens or pre-prepared ingredients due to our desire to provide tasty fresh food”. There are several menu items that indeed require extra time to create such as the ever popular ‘Rice and Six Curries’ the ‘Pescetarian Lamprais’ and the Sri Lankan ‘Big Village Breakfast’ for two. We sometimes ask late afternoon whether guests would like Chef to reserve a freshly caught fish or order one of the above items. At least 85% of our menu items however, can arrive at a table taking little or no more time than at any decent quality restaurant serving freshly made food. Sadly, in this world where processed, pre-packed fast-food has become the norm, even I forget sometimes just how long it can take to cook up a proper meal!   

Wine and in fact all foreign liquor attracts high import costs/duties/taxes and we are obliged to add government levies/taxes/VAT and service when selling it. Our policy is to avoid ‘marking up’ wine to a prohibitive level and experience thus far tells us that the majority of diners - even our long stay guests, happily order a bottle with their evening meal and, that its quality and cost can be viewed as equivelent to wine sold at a typical UK bistro. Quality of a product and its value to us is subjective. A view of value for money can be clouded by our own budget, exchange rates, cost to buy in our own country plus, a host of other factors. My own experience added to the large volume of guest feedback to date reassures me that our restaurant prices and moreover our value for money is comparative, just and fair. Finally on this, when I order wine at a restaurant myself, I always expect its cost to at least partially reflect the ambience, hospitality and exclusiveness of the estblishment at which I consume it. 

Music played at our restaurant. Generally, the jazz/swing, Latin with a sprinkling of classical/opera has proven very popular with guests so far and is now for some, part of the 'experience’ of being with us I’m told. I am frequently asked what music/artist is playing and for guests to share their own genre choices with us. Simply, a song to make absolutely everybody happy is yet to be written - until it is we’ll continue with our policy of playing fantastic music (my view!).  

Free bicycles. Many thanks for this feedback. I have just inspected them and several are now on their way to the repair shop! 

As for profit? Any made since this project opened 2 years ago has been reinvested. Investment goes directly to Team development, property upgrades/new facilities and guest services. 35 Sri Lankans (and their families comprising more than 100 individuals) currently benefit through; security of permanent, year round positions, training and development, fair wages and pensions etc. Many lives have been uplifted through past and current community initiatives including a voluntary 2 year, $1.2m donor funded/post tsunami project – still saving and improving lives today. Ongoing micro-sponsorship of a community pre-school and its teacher salaries is another example. You say “Not all what it seems!” – clearly another point on which we agree! 

My personal profit? A terrific team supporting me and caring for guests with utmost pride, my life in this paradise and most importantly - the diverse, interesting and appreciative clientele who come to stay with us. Perhaps if the hotel is successful and makes a good profit one day, nobody will begrudge me?

Again, thank you for coming to stay and sorry if we didn’t quite measure up. Please contact us with regards refunding your overpayment and please forgive the error – I assure you it was unintentional. Thank you.

I send Seasons Greeting and Best Wishes from Paradise. Nick.
placeInfo/address: Rekawa Beach Road Rekawa Village, Rekawa, Tangalle 82200 Sri Lanka
roomTip: Check the floor is not too slippy, there may be rooms with a safer floor surface!!
text: This was certainly a beautiful area of Sri Lanka, the walks along the beach are wonderful. My concern was the slippy concrete floor in the room which i nearly slipped on twice, not a good idea to walk bare foot! There is no brew facilities provided in the room. You can ask for this however, but the offer of morning tea and coffee first thing in the morning as a member of staff passed by seemed very inviting, so we accepted, only to find a bill for nearly £7 on check out! Nothing is ever free!!! The food needs to be ordered hours in advance, so if something is wrong, don't bother asking for something else, as you will have a long wait while your partner is at the coffee stage. The wine is ridiculously expensive and not the best quality. The music during dining takes you away from Sri Lanka and into a generic London Hotel! Overall it was a pleasant stay, but not sure about the prices. The bikes are in desperate need of maintenance too. Be nice to see some of the profits put back!!
title: Not all what it seems!

ownerResponse/text:
Firstly, thank you for your positive comment “we really like the place” and for giving me an opportunity to highlight issues for others to consider prior to travelling to the tropics, namely; weather, insects, expectations and communication.

Your stay in Sri Lanka coincided with unusual weather as you may recall. Prolonged heavy rain and a destructive cyclone may have caused a slight temporary increase in mosquitoes but with certainty the weather caused interruption to the growth and harvest patterns of all local produce along with all types of fishing. 

With regards mosquitoes in your suite; I respectfully remind you that within 20 minutes of us being aware of your concern, our housekeeping team issued new (and extra) plug-in repellents, sprayed the suite throughout with insect repellent, installed mosquito coils for the open air bathroom and checked for signs of infestation of which there were none – after this I inspected your suite personally. We do not provide mosquito nets as they have proven unnecessary thus far and quite simply, until your experience, this issue had not arisen, not even during your previous stay in the same suite. To offer a final perspective on this, after we had eradicated the (one night) problem you confirmed satisfaction with our action.

Room servicing; as you know we offer to service and re-service guest suites and supply new towels and/or bed linen every day if required. Further, I understand you had one complete change of linens during your 3 night stay – two sets for 3 nights. As a matter of course we do not provide a night turn-down service without request as many guests tell us how irritating this is elsewhere. This may explain why you found towels used after your morning room service exactly where you dropped them when returning to your suite later in the day.
 
Air conditioning; I remember saying “when air conditioning is used it’s rare to encounter mosquitoes” and with my apology offered an additional stand-fan for your comfort. You may not have understood me fully and therefore I apologise unreservedly for any miscommunication on my part. Virtually all guests use this everyday convenience, in fact the overwhelming majority would not even consider staying with us if it were not provided! Our classification as a boutique hotel and the demand for it requires that air-conditioning is installed throughout.
  
Mangoes; at your request we endeavoured to source ripe mangoes (two days running). I dispatched kitchen staff to the nearest town and village and personally asked our regular supplier to source them wherever he could and at whatever price – providing they were of suitable ripeness and quality. Due to the reason mentioned above (weather) and the fact that Sri Lanka does not import this fruit item, we were regrettably unable to add them to the abundance of fresh fruit and the exceptionally generous breakfasts the hotel offers. Chef will not prepare un-ripened or low quality fruit or other items to guests – regardless of pressure exerted by a guest and I must say, I believe quite rightly so.

Expectations and communication; when one travels overseas, particularly to developing countries in the tropics it is reasonable to anticipate that not everything we wish for or demand is necessarily available or easily managed. At times, insects or non-availability of certain items and the occasional inconvenience are only to be expected. Also, that as guests in another country perhaps we should accept that it's our own inability to communicate in that country’s 'mother tongue' that is the real barrier to good communication and, not necessarily the fault of innocent local staff. We can try to understand that; intimidating staff who are making genuine effort to please as I an others witnessed is not a solution. 

Sadly I must comment that (during and after your stay) I found it necessary to counsel members of my team whom felt insecure and immensely saddened by behaviour contrary to this perfectly acceptable view. Additionally, several guests were shocked by what they saw as a disproportionate and unnecessary reaction to a matter of relatively low importance. For these reasons I can no longer invite you to this hotel and can only add to your concluding statement of nothing is perfect, the the words; including ourselves at times. Nick Buckingham
placeInfo/address: Rekawa Beach Road Rekawa Village, Rekawa, Tangalle 82200 Sri Lanka
text:
We were there the second time and we really like the place. But this time we had problems
with Moskitos and other Insects. We asked for a Moskito-Net but were told, we should use 
the air-conditioning in our room, which will be enough to keep the Moskitos out. But as we 
do not like air-conditioning, we told this to the owner (Nick), but got the asnwer, there is no
need for Moskito-Nets and everybody uses air-conditioning, so we should use it as well! 

Also, we had small Ants in our beds and to be true, we never had so many bites and stiches
in our whole holidays in Sri Lanka! (5 weeks!) We left the place after 3 days, instead after 
5 days as planned. 
Breakfast is great, if you do not want to have f.e. Mangoes. We asked 3 days for Mangoes, but were told, Mangoes are not availlable. (You see Mangoes everywhere, in all places, in 
all forms and all states of ripeness!)

Room-Service is a bit poor. Towels where laying where we left them. Beds were just a bit 
straightend. No fresh towels, no fresh bed-sheets! 

Conclusion: Nothing is perfect!
title: nothing is perfect

text:
We were very particular about the sea view. We were given a room in the corner and the view was entirely disrupted with trees. Do not let them put you in “Indra” room. Plunge pool doesn’t have hot water. It was freezing cold. 

Food was good though.
title: If you want Sea View, do NOT go for “Indra” room from Sagara rooms

placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
text:
Aditya tries and there's nothing really wrong with it (apart from it's not inexpensive at US$230 per night ), it is just a little bland and without character. Not really a 'Boutique' hotel.

Rooms are large with outside bathrooms and a jacuzzi that is unheated so not over pleasant to linger in. The beach was clean but 'red flagged' for swimming; pool pleasant; exterior is rather 'block of flats' looking; staff almost over-attentive but there were very few guests & hardly anyone eating. Food adequate & I would hazard a guess that the croissants were from a previous day on 2 out of our 3 breakfasts .
The cutlery is terrible - an awkward shape that slides back into your food!

Galle is an easy 25 minute Tuk Tuk away but Front Desk were a little vague on availability or costs of other activities i.e whale watching, river safari etc 

Of our 4 hotels stayed in in Sri Lanka, Aditya was the least exciting. Ok but Average.
title: Just, well.... Average

placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
text:
Quite disappointed with the reviews here, the hotel has nice surroundings and amenities, but is way overpriced for what it is, in comparison with other hotels in the area. Certainly the term luxury doesn't apply here. Food is good but service is inconsistent. Most often there were literally no waiters around the pool area, and service was generally slow. You would sit down for breakfast or dinner, and people arriving after you would get their orders taken first, not for lack of us trying to get their attention. Don't ask for cocktails, although they are very willing and trying, they unfortunately do not know how to make a decent one
Reception is simply closed early in the morning. Although the food was good and the amenities pleasant, I can't see how people would pay so much money for this. Hopefully they will improve so that the service meets their advertising.
title: Not as advertised

ownerResponse/text: Dear Guest, Ayubown!! Your review made our day! Thank you for taking time to write such a review about our resort. It makes us really happy to know that you had an amazing stay with us. and we are extremely sorry for the bad experience you have faced due to an unclean beach area, we always make sure that the beach front within our boarders  very clean and we have no control over public beach area adjoining the hotel we are also very sorry about you not liking our food prepared by a very dedicated highly qualified team  whos Priority is about the making the guest happy all the time  but unfortunately in this rare case we have failed to meet your standards and regarding the hot tub first and foremost we do not  have a hot but what we have is a plunge pool designed with a natural look catering to our Clientele  who loves natural looking pools.it also has to be mentioned that we maintain international standards in cleaning all our pools with a advanced  filtration system used for our main pool yet again it is probably one rare occasion that we have received a complain about our pool.  We will surly circulate your review among our team and they would be glad to see that their efforts have made a difference and it has also motivated us as a team to be more alert in attending to matters such as yours. we will do our best not to let not just you or any of our guest face a situation like this ever again. since we are usually are a hotel that maintain very high standards Service.
placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
text:
This was the second hotel we stayed in as part of our honeymoon in Sri Lanka (the first was the Anantara). The hotel is located about 20 mins outside of Galle, so if your looking to be out of the hustle and bustle this is a good location as it's a bit more peaceful.

Pros:
The room was very large and spacious, and the staff did a great job keeping it clean, and adding little touches like laying candles and roses all of the floor! 

Friendly staff 

Cons:
The food at the restaurant was really not great, it is very average.

The pool seemed dirty. It didn't look like it had any cleaning system in it or if it did not a very good one.

The beach at the front was also quite dirty, with rubbish lying around everywhere. The staff could do a better job to keep the beach in front of the hotel clean. You also can not swim in the ocean as it's very aggressive.

The bathroom in the bedroom is sort of outside and gets very warm! The hot tub is huge but looked grimy and I really did not want to even sit in it, so gave it a miss!

For the price of the hotel you would think you would be getting a 5 star boutique, which this is definitely not. It's nice but not worth the money.
title: Nice boutique hotel but not worth what we paid

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Guest,

Ayubowan!!

Thank you for your review regarding our accommodation, Amenities, Location and service.
We invest a lot of time and effort to train our team to ensure the highest level of personalized service, However with regards to your comment about our hotel staff not being aware of HALAL food, we would like to inform you THAT ALL THE MEET WE SERVE IS HALAL. But due to the increase in demand and fluctuation in supply we do not patronize one supplier, However all our suppliers are HALAL certified.

We regret that our restaurant staff did not now the exact supplier from we have received the meet item that you ordered that week, However you may rest assured that all meet that we serve are HALAL certified.

Warm Regards,

placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
text:
Great boutique hotel in terms of accomodation, amenities, location and service. 

However unlikely to visit again as we were misled about the food. Booked based on advice that food served is all halal. We went there and found out that they have a mix of halal and non halal meat. Restaurant staff lack awareness of halal food. 

I have no problem if the hotel serves non halal food. But I have a problem if you claim you are halal when don't even know what you have in your kitchen. 

Everything else was perfect. The food was such a downer for us. Breakfast was good, dinner not so good.
title: Excellent suites

Thank you for your comment. We are happy to hear that you enjoyed our food & spread during your stay at Aditya. However we are sorry that our food portions were not upto your expectations.
 
Furthermore with regards to your comment about the beach being unclean, I’m sure you are aware that as the sea is rough during this period it collects a lot of waste on the shores. This however is being cleaned by the municipal council and not the hotel.

text:
Good food, lengthy menus but pretty small portions.
Nice beach front location but unclean beach.
Extremely poooooor services.... No house keeping during our two night stay... even after making 3 requests. Services with in-room dining is also way below the average. Highly incompetent even to provide some extra bread for 15mins during breakfast, which ended up half way without bread.
